page.lettertext:
fol.191r
to
e
Whereas I was enjoyned by her
Ma
ties
Instructions, to requyre
of the
States
certaine shippes of warre, for
e service of
Brittanie,
I besought your L: by my l
re
s of
e 26 of
Maye, to signifie what nomber her Ma
tie
would furnish,
to
e ende I might insist
at according to
e Treatie,
they should arme as manie more, which I sollicited
alsoe after, by l
re
s of
e 11 and 24 of June, and 10
of July.
The 19 of July I had one from your L. of
e 7 of the
same mo
n
eth, which was the first
at I receaved fr
o
the time of my departure; wherein you made me no
aunswear, to
e principall point of my foresaid l
re
s,
but onely in yt willed me to reco
m
end unto
e States
certain speciall demaundes, which her Ma
tie
in person
had delivered
M
r
Caron
: whereof noe Copie was sent
unto me, nor any note or specification, to what effect
they might tend. Nevertheles, to execute my charge,
I caused
e States to assemble upon it, and after I had
used some speeches unto them, to hasten their assistance,
I desyred their aunswear to
e foresaid demandes. But
they in their aunswear declared unto me,
at as yet they
had no notice of any demaundes, and therfore they required
me, to exhibit them in writing, or to signifie by worde,
what matter they contained. And when they found by
my replie,
at I was ignorant altogether of
at which I
requyred, I leave to be considered what they thought
among themselves, and howe ill it did beseeme me to come
to them in their meeting, to inquyre her Hig
es
pleasure
especially in those causes which they expected from me,
and for which her Ma
tie
sent me purposely to negotiat
with the
Provinces
./
fol.191v
The 20 daye of July they heard from M
r
Caron, and rece
aved
those demandes, which were made of her Hig
es
, in which
they
founde dyvers doubtes of speciall importance, which they
depu-
ted certaine persons to co
m
unicat with me presently, s
uppo-
sing, as it seemed,
at I had alsoe then receaved full instructions
[.]
in every point. But perceaving as before
at I was a
stran-
ger to
e matter, they themselves acquaynted me with M
r
Carons letters, and with a postscript of his, by which they
were advertised,
at by order of her Hig
es
,
e present prop
osal
of
e foresaid demandes was countermanded. And with
[all]
they made shewe to be greatlie mooved, beyng left in
some
perplexitie,
at by my relation they knewe nothing, a
[.]
by their Agent but uncertaintie. Wherupon they req
uyred
me to use some diligence, to learne her Hig
es
last a
nd de-
terminat purpose; aswell in respect of
at, which she
her
self would perfourme, as also of that which she requyred
of
them, to
e end they might arme their Navie according
ly
and frame the course of their provisions for
e benefit of
e Provinces, and
e best advauncem
t
of the service:
For they might otherwise be soe bourdened with u
n
ecessary
charges, as at an other tyme heere after, they should
hardly
be able to drawe
e people to contribut to anie suche e
nterprise
Of this I certified yo
r
L.
by 2 privat l
re
s the 21 of July, and by
an
other of
the 28
of July
, and 7 of Au
gust
most earnestly craving an expedit aunswear.
The 12 of August I receaved one from your L. of
e 3
of
same moneth: by which I was advertised,
at notwithstand
ing
e foresaid countermande of her Ma
ties
demandes, she did
afterwardes approove M
r
Carons carefull dealing in m
aking
his dispatch. And although at
e same tyme
e states h
ad
understoode of
at allowance of her Ma
tie
, yet because they h
ad
intelligence,
at
e first appointed generals of her Hig
es
fo
rces
my
L. Admirall
and My
L. of Essex
, were not to be imployed
fol.192r
they misdoubted therupon
at some other alteration would ensue
in other pointes (whereof there is noe question, but insi-
nuation was made by their Agent unto them) for which
they mooved me againe with very great instance, to en-
devo
r
with speede to knowe some finall resolution: of
which also they desired to be directly and precisely in-
formed by me, and not by M
r
Caron: because (as they
alleadged) I was sent expressely to them, and whatsoever
in those matters they proposed to
e Provinces, as from
their owne servant, it would by no meanes be accepted as
sufficient and autenticall. To which effect I writte
unto you
e 15 of August, with signification of repugn
a
ce
betwixt the l
re
s of your L., and M
r
Carons advertisements,
by meanes whereof, and for want of plaine intelligence
of her Hig
es
full intention, I was very muche confounded
in my dealing with
e States: who urged me continuallie
to an orderly proceeding, by proposing roundly to them,
and in her Ma
ties
name, as I had ever bin wonted, her
determinat pleasure.
The 8 of Sep
t
I receaved your l
re
answear bearing date
e 27 of Au
g
by which you seemed muche offended,
charging me with precisenesse and cavillation, and with
some note of worse dealing, then my long and faithfull
service had any waye deserved, or your L. I trust doth
conceave at this p
nt
. And although in
at l
re
, there
was nothing contained
at
e States expected, and I had writ-
ten for soe often, yet by earnest sollicitation, I obtained
soe much, as they dispatched then p
nt
ly sixe shippes well
appointed, and other three they promised to send presently
after./
